element.name: Ardgillan V "Across the tracks" by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

long-description.p: In 1658 the Down Survey indicates that Ardgillan was owned by wine merchant Robert Usher of Crumlin, Dublin and by 1737, the property had been acquired by the Reverend Robert Taylor, one of the Headfort Taylors, whose grandfather had collaborated with Sir William Petty on the mid 17th Century "Down Survey of Ireland". Ardgillan remained the family home of the Taylors (later changed to Taylour) for more two hundred years until 1962 when the estate was sold to Heinrick Pott of Westphalia, Germany. In 1982 Dublin County Council purchased Ardgillan Demesne and it is now managed by Fingal Council.

The residence at Ardgillan is a large country-style house with castellated embellishments. Originally named "Prospect", the central section was built in 1738 by Robert Taylor, with the west and east wings added in the late 1700's.
Initially the site was heavily wooded, the name Ardgillan being derived from the Irish "Ard Choill" meaning High Wood. It was cleared by out-of-service soldiers and itinerant workers in return for one penny a day, sleeping accommodation and one meal.
As part of an agreement to allow the Dublin to Belfast railway line to be constructed on the eastern boundry a clause was inserted to wit Robert Taylor could stop and board the trains at anytime he choose.
This cache cannot be access from the roadway you must enter either the main estate entrance or the "Ladies Stairs" entrance.

The Cache is a decon box.
Please take care and rehide the cache to prevent muggles from discovering its location.

ul.li:
2010-05-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by medic143
Last of three in Balbriggan, surprisingly easy off accurately coordinates. Got lucky this time [:-)]
TNLN TFTC

2010-04-24T19:00:00Z : Found it by theswerve
Found after the CITO and a spot of lunch in Rush...what better way to finish the day??

2010-04-24T19:00:00Z : Found it by Fjon
Found easily after the CITO event - thanks.

2010-04-24T19:00:00Z : Found it by Donnacha
Found after attending the CITO. Thanks.

2010-04-24T19:00:00Z : Found it by orangetigerprawn
Found while out and about after the CITO event.
Go raibh maith agat as an taisce.

wpt.name: GC20WCF
wpt.desc: Ardgillan V "Across the tracks" by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Ardgillan V "Across the tracks"
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Ardgillan Demise

In 1658 the Down Survey indicates that Ardgillan was owned by wine merchant Robert Usher of Crumlin, Dublin and by 1737, the property had been acquired by the Reverend Robert Taylor, one of the Headfort Taylors, whose grandfather had collaborated with Sir William Petty on the mid 17th Century "Down Survey of Ireland". Ardgillan remained the family home of the Taylors (later changed to Taylour) for more two hundred years until 1962 when the estate was sold to Heinrick Pott of Westphalia, Germany. In 1982 Dublin County Council purchased Ardgillan Demesne and it is now managed by Fingal Council.

The residence at Ardgillan is a large country-style house with castellated embellishments. Originally named "Prospect", the central section was built in 1738 by Robert Taylor, with the west and east wings added in the late 1700's.
Initially the site was heavily wooded, the name Ardgillan being derived from the Irish "Ard Choill" meaning High Wood. It was cleared by out-of-service soldiers and itinerant workers in return for one penny a day, sleeping accommodation and one meal.
As part of an agreement to allow the Dublin to Belfast railway line to be constructed on the eastern boundry a clause was inserted to wit Robert Taylor could stop and board the trains at anytime he choose.

The Cache

This cache cannot be access from the roadway you must enter either the main estate entrance or the "Ladies Stairs" entrance.

The Cache is a decon box.
Please take care and rehide the cache to prevent muggles from discovering its location.







The Windsockers
